Devices.Name: Temperature Sensor
Devices.Description: This Temperature Sensor device sends periodic readings in degrees centigrade. It is accurate to +/- 1 degree between -10 and +40 degrees centigrade
Devices.LongDescription: Using a thermistor this wireless temperature sensor will tell you the ambient temperature of its environment. The device sends periodic encrypted temperature readings to other WirelessThings devices. It is accurate to +/- 1 degree between -10 and +40 degrees centigrade. The internal coin cell battery is capable of running for well in excess of 10 years (based on 1 reading per hour).

Actions.Description: Return the temperature in degrees centigrade
Return the temperature in degrees centigrade

Devices.Name: Ambient Light Level Sensor
Devices.Description: This Ambient Light Sensor device sends periodic readings of light as a percentage.
Devices.LongDescription: Using a light dependent resistor (LDR), this wireless light sensor measures and sends you periodical readings, of the ambient light level of its environment. The light level is represented as a percentage, with 100% being very bright and 0% very dark. The internal coin cell battery is capable of running for well in excess of 10 years (based on 1 reading per hour).

Actions.Description: Return the light level as a percentage

Devices.Name: Humidity and Temperature
Devices.Description: This Humidity and Temperature Sensor device sends periodic readings of relative humidity and temperature in degrees centigrade.
Devices.LongDescription: Using a Sensirion SHT21 sensor, this device measures and sends you periodical readings, of both the humidity and temperature of its environment. The humidity level is represented as relative humidity RH and temperature is in degrees centigrade.

Actions.Description: Return the current relative humidity reading
Return the current temperature in degrees centigrade

Devices.Name: Button KeyFob
Devices.Description: The Wireless KeyFob can have one to five buttons depending on the model, each sends its own Language of Things message that can be used to control our other devices or any other system you can think of.
Devices.LongDescription: The Wireless KeyFob can have one to five buttons depending on the model, each sends its own Language of Things message that can be used to control our other devices or any other system you can think of. Examples include switching a device on/off to sending an email. Buttons are identified by the letters A to E. A full five button key fob starts with A in the middle and then B at the top, C, D and E are clockwise from there. A three button key fob (horizontal layout) will thus have button E at the left, button A in the centre and button C at the right.

Actions.Description: Indicates which button has been pressed [A-E], note actual command name can be set via MSG option

Options.Description: Set message for the button press (Default BUTTON)

Devices.Name: Lux light level sensor
Devices.Description: This Lux Light Sensor device sends periodic readings of light in LUX.
Devices.LongDescription: Using a TSL2591 digital Lux Light Sensor this devcice provides a more absolute reading of ligth level. The lux (symbol: lx) is the SI unit of illuminance and luminous emittance, measuring luminous flux per unit area. It is equal to one lumen per square metre. The LUX sensor reports the absolute LUX value, this has approximately been calibrated for the supplied container, note that the reading will vary according to the direction of the incident light.

Actions.Description: Return the current Lux reading. Result of 88888 indicates the LUX is too bright for the sensor (rated at 88000 lux)

Options.Description: Set the calibration value â€“ this is a floating point number and the measured LUX will be multiplied by this value to give the calibrated LUX. This is to allow for the attenuation of the box and slots as well as the positioning of the sensor.

Devices.Name: Barometric Pressure and Temperature sensor
Devices.Description: This Barometric Pressure and Temperature device sends periodic reading of Pressure in millibars (hPa) and Temerature in degrees centigrade
Devices.LongDescription: Using the high accuracy MPL3115A2 this devce gives Barometric Pressure in millibars (hPa) and Temerature in degrees centigrade. Relative accuracy during pressure change between 70 to 110 kPa at any constant temperature between -10 Â°C to 50 Â°C is +-0.05kPa (or +-0.5 millibar). Relative accuracy during changing temperature between -10 Â°C to 50 Â°C at any constant pressure between 50 kPa to 110 kPa is +- 0.1kPa (or +-1millibar). Resolution accuracy is typically 1.5Pa. Temperature accuracy is  +-1 degree C at 25 degrees, and +-3 degrees over the temperature range.

Actions.Description: Return the current pressure in millibars (hPa)
Return the current temperature in degrees centigrade

Devices.Name: Dual State Switch Sensor
Devices.Description: Dual State Switch Sensor takes an input reading (from a switch it is wired to) to alert you of the switches change of state. (i.e from OPEN to CLOSED
Devices.LongDescription: Dual State Switch Sensor takes an input reading (from a switch it is wired to) to alert you of the switches change of state. (i.e from OPEN to CLOSED

Actions.Description: Switch state, note actual command name can be set via MSG option

Options.Description: Sleep period whilst waiting for sensor to return to off (Default 100)

Devices.Name: Tilt Switch Sensor
Devices.Description: Tilt Switch Sensor takes an input reading from a tilt sensor when disturbed, (similar to a ball bearing in a tube) to alert you of the devices movement
Devices.LongDescription: Tilt Switch Sensor takes an input reading from a tilt sensor when disturbed, (similar to a ball bearing in a tube) to alert you of the devices movement

Actions.Description: Tilt state, note actual command name can be set via MSG option

Options.Description: Sleep period whilst waiting for sensor to return to off (Default 100)
